briefing.opening: Good morning. We will now begin the climate briefing for February 8, 2026. Today, as efforts to achieve carbon neutrality and expand renewable energy continue both domestically and internationally, warnings about the impacts of global climate change and future risks are also drawing significant attention.

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Carbon Neutrality Practices Expanding from Education to Industry
sections.content: Today, news highlighted the expansion of carbon neutrality efforts across various sectors in Korea, from educational institutions to industries and local communities. Notably, the Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education plans to mandate carbon neutrality practices in all schools starting in 2026, enhance energy efficiency through the introduction of self-diagnosis tools, and operate 44 key schools, thereby expanding field-oriented, customized support [3, 4, 6, 8, 11, 12, 14, 15, 16, 20, 21]. Furthermore, Chungnam Province is promoting carbon neutrality practices linked to senior employment [5], Seosan City is seeking a major transformation from being the 'heart of petrochemicals' to a 'global carbon neutrality outpost' [7], and Ulleung County is initiating an electric vehicle dissemination project with the goal of becoming an eco-friendly island [13]. These efforts reflect the unique characteristics of each region. Concurrently, Hyundai Mobis is accelerating its decarbonization transition with the goal of 'parts manufacturer-type carbon neutrality' [9], and Busan's Yeongdo District received an 'A' rating in its carbon neutrality plan evaluation, recognizing it as a leading city [18].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Strengthening Climate Crisis Adaptation and Corporate ESG Management
sections.content: Noteworthy news also included local governments' efforts to adapt to the climate crisis and companies' strengthened ESG management. Gyeongnam Province is enhancing public official capabilities on the front lines of climate crisis response [2, 10, 17], and is implementing practical adaptation measures, such as investing 3.7 billion won to support structural improvements for beekeeping farms struggling due to the climate crisis [1]. Meanwhile, Samsung Biologics completed third-party verification of its product carbon footprint and obtained global certification, marking a significant step towards advancing its ESG management [19, 22, 23, 24]. Such voluntary corporate efforts are setting new management standards in the era of climate change.

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Renewable Energy Transition Domestically and Internationally
sections.content: Domestic and international companies and local governments are actively moving to accelerate the transition to renewable energy. Gyeongsangnam-do plans to comprehensively expand its renewable energy dissemination projects by 2026, contributing to increased village income, RE100 achievement, and improved welfare [25, 30]. Korea Electric Power Corporation (KEPCO) successfully secured 700 billion won in project financing for a renewable energy project in Guam without guarantees, demonstrating international trust [26]. Shinhan Bank is supporting domestic companies' overseas expansion by assisting with renewable energy investments in the U.S. alongside Hanwha Solutions [28, 34]. Notably, Korea Zinc's Australian renewable energy subsidiary, Ark Energy, is gaining momentum in Australia's eco-friendly business by signing a long-term energy service contract with the New South Wales government [27, 29, 31, 32, 33, 35, 36]. Internationally, China's plan to strengthen its battery sector for clean energy transition [45] is also raising expectations for advancements in renewable energy technology and expanded deployment.

sections.title: âš ï¸ Global Climate Change Impacts and Future Risk Warnings
sections.content: Meanwhile, warnings about the impacts of global climate change and future risks cannot be overlooked. Meteorological agencies and climate scientists point to the possibility of an El NiÃ±o developing in the Pacific later this year, with one expert warning that 2027 could be hotter than the record high temperatures of the past three years [46]. Chilly weather is highlighting unresolved questions about the effects of climate change [37, 38], and there are also reports that climate change is altering avalanche patterns [39] or introducing dangerous invasive species into the Venetian lagoon [42]. While some regions are reportedly not yet experiencing the impacts of climate change [40], concerns about human intolerance and climate change are growing [44].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Climate Policy and Responsible Corporate Actions
sections.content: In the international community, the formulation of policies to address climate change and responsible corporate actions are continuously being called for. The University of Florida's (UF) new climate action plan is currently on indefinite hold [41], illustrating the challenges in climate policy development. However, British Columbia (B.C.) demonstrated policy flexibility by changing mandatory electric vehicle regulations related to emissions to incentives for vehicles under $50,000 [45]. On a positive note, pharmaceutical company Lupin achieved an 'A-' leadership rating from CDP (Carbon Disclosure Project) in both climate change and water security categories [43], indicating international recognition for corporate environmental disclosure and sustainable management efforts.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing highlighted the diverse efforts underway both domestically and internationally to address the climate crisis and achieve carbon neutrality, while simultaneously reminding us of the severe impacts of climate change and the clear need to acknowledge future warnings. This concludes today's climate briefing.
